titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I rose this Morning between nine and ten O’Clock. The swelling and inflammation about the eye still diminishes, but more slowly than I had hoped— I have yet restless Nights; and the eye requires washing some times in the Night— Lucy sleeps on a mattress in the chamber, and I called her up once or twice last Night— Mr Grubb made this Morning a Copy of Lord Bathurst’s Note, concerning the taking away of Downman’s slaves, and with Mrs Adams compared it as well as the copy of the other Note, which he had made out before, with the Originals, and then took them to town, with a packet for the Secretary of State, and one for my father, to be dispatched as soon as possible to America— He took also my answer to the Letter from Messrs: Glennie, Son and Co. I requested him to call at the Foreign Office, and let Mr Morier know the impossibility I am now under, of calling upon him, but that I will take the first opportunity of calling, when sufficiently recovered to go out— Mr Grubb called accordingly, and left the Message— Mr Morier himself had not yet returned to the Office— Mr Grubb sent me out, by the Coachman, a new Note in 24 folio pages, from Lord Bathurst, on the subject of fisheries— I cannot for the present reply to it—but it must not be kept without reply— It is dated on the 30th: of October. At dusk this afternoon I removed from the dressing chamber to the drawing Room, and was part of the Evening there. Mrs Adams began to use it for her dining room— She also wrote for me a few short notes for my journal, from the time when I was obliged to suspend writing it, and of course, beginning with Saturday the 14th: of October— From those Minutes the arrears of this Book, are if possible to be retrieved— The Journal of a sick chamber cannot however be long, and may perhaps to the writer and sufferer, not be tedious.

2. When Dr Cook came to visit me this morning, he found me so far convalescent that he said to me— “Well, Sir, we have saved your eye.” He attributes more to his own agency in this favourable turn of my disease, that I think it deserves. That he mistook the nature of the complaint is certain; and I strongly believe that a more powerful application of physic at the first would have saved me from all its violence; and from the necessity of the leaches or of the blister— These did perhaps become necessary, and have been very useful; but it is not to the physician, that I can give the glory of my recovery. He has strongly recommended it to me, to consult a professed and eminent oculist, as soon as I shall be well enough to go out— He recommends a Dr Travers whom he considers as one of the most skilful men in that branch of the medical department, now in England— He proposes going to him with me, and this day wrote to him to enquire when we might be sure of finding him at home— Mrs. Adams, and our Son John who is recovering from his fever, went this day into London; and returned to dinner, about six— Mrs Von Harten called to pay her a visit, while she was gone.— It being a half-holiday at school, George sat with me, and recited to me, fifty lines of Homer— He also read to me, from Miss Edgworth’s Early Lessons, the Tale of Eton Montem— I can yet bear so little light, that another person can barely see in my chamber sufficiently to read to me— The Doctor has relaxed the rule for my diet, and allows me a little animal food and wine.

3. My wife was very ill, and confined to her bed the whole day, in consequence of a Cold, which she took yesterday in going to Town. I had also myself a sort of a relapse— For the inflammation which has not yet entirely subsided in my left eye, has this day fallen upon the right one, and all the latter part of the day it has been very painful. Dr Nicholas’s daughters called, to pay a visit to Mrs Adams, but she was too ill to receive them. I was doubtful, whether I should be able to go out of the house to-morrow, but Dr Cook advised that I should— He received an answer from Dr Travers, that he should be at home to-morrow, until one o’clock, and will see me at any time before that hour.— This was one of the most tedious days that I have had; but George recited to me fifty lines of Homer, and read Miss Edgworth’s Tale of barring out— I am still obliged to live in a great measure in darkness— This Evening there was a Letter from Mr Grubb— We began to be concerned for the arrival of our effects from St. Petersburg— Three weeks have passed since I received the Bill of lading— Nothing yet has been heard of the vessel in which they were shipped; and there have been several extremely violent gales upon the Coast, and much shipping lost within the last ten days— Mr Grubb has several times urged me to make insurance, upon our effects, which he thought might be done upon moderate terms— I asked him yesterday to make enquiry, how it could be effected, and he now writes me that the Underwriters do not admire such risks, and that the premium may vary from 5 to 40 per Cent— I determined therefore to take the chances for myself.

4. Mrs: Adams was very ill the whole Night, but much better this morning— The inflammation of my left eye has rather increased again, yesterday and last Night, and that of the right eye has continued and assumed a threatening appearance.— I had an uneasy and sleepless Night; but the day being fine, I sent early this Morning to Dr Cook, requesting him to call here at ten O’Clock, and if he thought I could safely venture out, to go with me into London, to see and consult Dr Travers.— Dr Cook came at ten, and thought I might go— He went with me,
Dr Travers lives at N 8. New Broad Street in the City; upwards of ten miles distant from my house— As I had been eleven days confined to a warm chamber; and as the day was cold, I took my Russian furr’d surtout and Boots, which I found however too warm— We reached Dr Travers’s house about one O’Clock— Dr Cook, and myself described to him the condition in which my eyes had been; and he saw the State in which they now are— He approved of the course of the treatment of them hitherto, but he told Dr Cook that my complaint was not the Egyptian Opthalmia; though in some of the symptoms resembling it. He assured me that the disorder was altogether superficial, and the Vision in no sort of danger— He advised me to return for some days to a low diet, recommended the immediate application of leaches to the right eye, and also the use of a light poultice upon the eye-lid if it could bear it. He mentioned the composition of a wash for the left eye, of rose-water and a solution of alum, and asked me to call upon him again, when the inflammation should be dispersed, intimating that he might then supply me some permanent remedy, for the habitual disorder of the eyes with which I am afflicted. Dr Cook left me there having some other visits to pay, before returning home— After he was gone, I expressed some reluctance to the application of leaches to my right eye; and upon what I said, Dr Travers, advised me to postpone the use of them for two or three days— He said he did not know how the inflammation could be dispersed without them, but possibly it might; and it could do no harm to wait a day or two and see if it would— The attack on that side, he said was not very vigorous, and that on the other had spent its force.— He told me that he was acquainted with Dr Post of New-York, and with his brother— I left him about two O’Clock, and reached home by four— Not much fatigued, but rather refreshed by the exercise of the ride. Dr Cook came late in the Evening with the rose-water and alum wash; and with the leaches— He left them here, but upon my telling him what Dr Travers had last said, consented to postpone the use of them for a day or two— He had walked the whole way home from Dr Travers’s house.— I found Mrs Adams much recovered from her yesterday’s and last Night’s illness— Mr Grubb sent me out last Evening, and I received this Morning a Card from the City Remembrancer, with an invitation from the Lord Mayor Elect (Wood) to the great annual Entertainment, on the Lord Mayor’s day—next Thursday the 9th. of this Month— The Answer was to be sent directed to the City Remembrancer, at Guildhall— Mrs Adams wrote and sent an excuse for me; as it will be impossible for me to attend.

5. My wife was this day entirely recovered. I had myself a more quiet night than any of the last fortnight, and the exercise of yesterday was undoubtedly serviceable to me— The inflammation of both my eyes had subsided, so that Dr Cook consented to defer for another day the application of Leaches to the right eye— Dr Travers had also recommended to lay a light poultice of bread and milk upon the inflamed part of the eye-lid— It was accordingly tried when I went to bed last Night, but the eye was too weak, and sore to bear it, and it was immediately taken away. Dr Travers asked me yesterday if my Spirits had not been much affected; I told him they had; but that I had taken Patience, as one of the best remedies of the disease— He said it was, and I have found it better than either of those prescribed by him. I rose this morning about ten— There were visits from Mr Von Harten and Mr F. Nicholas, and Major and Mrs Morison, Miss Blair and Miss Carnell— I was too unwell and Mrs Adams not inclined to see visitors, so they all left Cards— George read to me Buckminster’s Sermon upon the Character of St Peter, which I think much better than that of Sterne, upon the same Subject.— Mr Grubb last Evening sent me out two Letters which I received this morning— One from Messrs: Glennie, Son and Co. containing a statement of their account with the Navy Department, leaving them in advance between five and six thousand pounds Sterling— They add that Mr M’Call wants to draw about £8000 more, but they have requested him not to draw, until they shall receive further remittances, that if they have not an order upon the agent of the Treasury here for the funds, they must draw upon the Navy Department, and in selling their Bills, do not expect to obtain for them more than three shillings Sterling for the Dollar— The other Letter was from Messrs: W. E. & E. B. Lawrence, dated Trinity Square, and relating to the case of the American Ship Hope, Obed Chase, Master, captured in May 1814. at Anchor in the Port of Buenos Ayres, by the British Frigate Neveus, brought here and condemned last December.— Messrs Lawrence, as agents for the American owners, wish to appeal from the Sentence, on the ground of the violation of the neutral Jurisdiction in the Capture. They have applied to the Spanish Ambassador, who refuses to interfere, on the principle that Buenos Ayres was in a state of Insurrection against the Government of Spain; and that by the Spanish Laws, no foreign vessel, could have been admitted, or consequently taken, there, by a British Frigate.— Messrs: Lawrence ask my assistance, but they state, that the appeal must be entered at latest; by the beginning of next Month, and can be entered only on the ground of the
violation of the neutral Jurisdiction— I have therefore no power to authorize the appeal. Mrs. Adams wrote this Evening to Mr Grubb, requesting him to come out here to-morrow.

6. Rose between nine and ten, and having no further need of a Nurse in the Night, Lucy has returned to her own chamber. The inflammation of my right eye is so nearly dispersed that Dr Cook consented to omit the application of Leaches to it, altogether. A more persevering abstinence, and more powerful physic, I am persuaded would have saved me from it entirely, and from much that I have suffered in the other. The recovery of that is very slow, and the blister has left a troublesome sore. This morning I rode out in the Carriage with Mrs Adams and John, about five Miles on the Uxbridge Road. I took my Russian Surtout and furred Boots; but found them too warm— Mrs Adams was unwell after the ride— The Letter written last Evening to Mr Grubb, requesting him to come out this day, was dispatched this Morning, and not being dated he thought on receiving it that the invitation was for to-morrow, and did not come this day— But I received this Evening a Note from him promising to come to morrow, and enclosing two Letters— One from Mr Alexander Hammett, Consul of the United States at Naples, and the other from Mr R. W. Fox, the Consul at Falmouth. Mr Hammett encloses three Documents proving that four Negro Slaves were enticed away from the plantation of a Mr Borden in Virginia, by Captain Vaux, Master of a British merchant vessel, and carried to Naples— Mr Hammett applied to the British Minister at Naples to recover them; but was answered by the British Pro-Consul, and referred for a remedy to the tribunals.— Mr Hammett is not satisfied with this reference, but I do not see that there can be a resort to any other— Mr Fox consents that his nephew shall not act as Vice-Consul at Plymouth, but thinks that Mr Ingraham ought to be commissioned by himself.

7. I now rise with some regularity between nine and ten— My right eye has almost entirely recovered, but the state of the other improves so slowly, that I can yet bear only a small portion of daylight, and pass the day still in the dressing chambers though in the Evening I can adjourn to the drawing room. The weather was this day so damp, and unpleasant that Mrs Adams and John both declined riding out with me— I rode however to Brentford, and to Aston, and at both places endeavoured to procure an eye cup, with which the Doctors have directed me to wash my eyes, in the Collyrium of Rose-water and alum. I did not succeed, and returned from a short ride by the way of Ealing.— The want of some occupation, presses upon me heavily— My wife continues to make short minutes for my Journal; and this day, began writing for me, under my dictation, a Letter to my Mother— Mr Grubb came out, and brought the welcome intelligence of the arrival at Gravesend of the Ann, Captain Perkin, with our Effects from St: Petersburg— I dictated and Mr Grubb wrote for me, answers to two or three Letters, which required the most immediate attention— A Note to Mr W. Vaughan enclosing for Dr Rees, a copy of the comparative view of the results of the three Censuses of the United States, which I had made some time since, and promising the last printed Census itself— A short Letter to the Secretary of State, enclosing the Copy of Lord Bathurst’s Note, concerning the fisheries; and an Answer to the last Letter from Mr Fox at Falmouth.

8. Mr Grubb and Mrs Adams compared the copy of Lord Bathurst’s Note upon the fisheries with the original, and after having the packets for America, made up, I rode into London, and Mr Grubb returned with me. I found at the Office a written Notification from Messrs: Smith and Sons Brokers of the arrival of our effects by the Ann Captain Perkin; with a requisition to send and have them taken away immediately.— Mr Grubb went out and procured me an eye-cup. While he was out, Mrs Withy, the wife of the man, who lives in the house where I keep my Office, and of whom I hire it, came and gave me a Letter from her Son, who has held for these four years an office of Clerk in the Navy-Office here, and who expects to be discharged on the reduction of the Establishment consequent upon the present state of General Peace;—and he requests my interference to recommend him to a situation, at home or abroad.— I told Mrs Withy that, I should be very glad to serve her son if it should be in my power; but I knew of no situation to which I could recommend him with any prospect of being useful to him— Should any such occur, I would very readily recommend him— I remained only a short time in town, and returned home before five O’Clock. Dr Cook this day intermitted his visit for the first time since I was seized with the complaint in my eyes.

9. Lord Mayor’s day; and it was celebrated with extraordinary and unusual Splendour. I regretted that I had been obliged to decline the invitation to attend it. Instead of which I was inflexibly confined to the house; and almost to my chamber— The weather was damp and windy— I made preparation to take a short walk in the Garden, but was dissuaded from it as an excess of imprudence—
Dr Cook again omitted his visit, this day.— In the Evening I received a Note from Mr Grubb, who had been into the City to procure our baggage, from St. Petersburg at the Custom-House— We had concluded to have them sent by Water to Kew Bridge and wished if possible to have them put on board the boat, immediately from the vessel; but this was not to be obtained at the Custom-House— They must be landed. Mr Grubb has agreed with a boatman to take them to Kew-Bridge for £2: and has promised him that if he is careful of them he shall have the job of bringing them from the boat to the house. He sends to ask for the bill of lading and the keys— I received also a Note from Mr W. Vaughan, in reply to my Letter of the 7th: and a Letter from Mr T. English, Consul of the United States at Dublin— He encloses to me an Act of Parliament, concerning Ship-Letters, of the operation of which he complains both as affecting his official correspondence, and the convenience of the commercial intercourse between the United States and Ireland— It is like the ship-letter Act lately repealed here— Mr English complains also of a regulation, by which American Vessels are allowed to take from Ireland, only one passenger for every five tons, while British Vessels, are permitted to take a passenger for every two tons— But where is the remedy for all this to be found?— Also a Letter from Mr Robert Mowbray at Leith.

10. I sent Pio into London, with the Bill of Lading and the keys of the trunks arrived from St Petersburg; to procure them from the Custom House.— Received this Morning a second Note from Mr Grubb written last Evening; Pio returned this Evening, with another Letter from Mr Grubb written this day— They found the usual obstructions and difficulties at the Custom House, and after much bustle, and trouble, could not obtain the effects— Nothing but a promise that they should be landed to-morrow, and deposited at the King’s Warehouses— All which is granted as special favour and courtesy. Dr Cook paid me his last visit for the present. I am to cease henceforth the use of medecines, and only to wash my eyes often with the Collyrium; and to return gradually to my customary diet— After eighteen days of confinement from walking in the open air, I this day took a walk for a quarter of an hour in the garden; wearing a pair of green eye glasses, and a green silk shade over them— Afterwards I rode out with Mrs Adams and John— We went over Kew Bridge, to Richmond Hill, and through the Park— Mrs Adams finished writing for me, the Letter to my Mother, begun last Tuesday. Continued also the minutes for the Journal, down to last Evening.— George recites to me, every Evening, fifty lines of Homer— I received this Evening a second Letter from Mrs Eliza Giles, requesting me to supply her with means of finishing the education of one of her Sons, and of supporting herself, and a daughter in ill-health, a request with which it is altogether out of my power to comply.— Had a Letter also from Messrs: Joseph Fox, and E. Schwabe, Secretaries of the British and Foreign School Society, with an invitation to me to attend the General Meeting of the Institution to be held at Freemason’s Hall, on Saturday the 25th. of this Month— The Letter is dated the 27th: of last Month, and to facilitate the preliminary arrangements, requests an early answer.— As it is doubtful whether the condition of my eyes will then admit of my going, I shall decline at all Events the invitation— When I was in London last Tuesday, three American Sailors applied to me, for assistance; each having a Story to tell, and having all served on board of our public ships during the late war.— I desired Mr Grubb, to write a line to Mr Beasley in their behalf— Grubb sent me this Evening an answer from Mr Beasley’s Clerk, Williams, concerning them.

11. IX. I Went into London, with my Son John, and took Pio with me— Sent him to the Custom-House for our baggage, but with no better success than before— When we arrived at the Office in Charles Street, Mr Grubb was not there— He returned about 2 O’Clock from the Custom-House. Pio came about an hour afterwards— The effects are at last landed, and lodged in the King’s warehouses— Mr Grubb had written me last Evening another Note from the New-England Coffee-House, about them, which I received this Morning. They are to be ready to be sent by the Boat on Monday, when the tide will serve favourably for shooting London Bridge— I found at the Office a Letter, from Judge William Cranch, recommending to me, Mr Charles Bennett of Alexandria, who he says, he understands, visits England, rather from motives of health and amusement than Business— Mr Bennett left the Letter at the Office yesterday, and intimated that he had some business, upon which he wished to converse with me, and that he would call again. I went twice to the foreign Office to see Mr Morier, in consequence of his note of the twenty-seventh of last Month. The second time I found him there— He said that he had sent to ask to see me, in order to mention that the Lieutenant Governor of Gibraltar, at the request of Commodore Decatur, had permitted some naval Stores, belonging to the American Squadron to be landed and to be deposited in the place where the king’s Stores were kept— That the Prince Regent had approved of the conduct of the Commander at Gibraltar in this instance, and he was charged to say to me that if it should be signified by me to be the wish of the Government of the United States, that a similar convenience should be afforded to the American Naval force, in the Mediterranean, Instructions to that effect should be given to the commanding Officers, both at Gibraltar and Malta. But
if it should be merely the request of the Commanders of the Squadrons, it would be liable to other considerations. He said also that Mr Bernard Henry, had presented himself as Consul of the United States at Gibraltar— He had been recognized in that capacity by the Lieutenant Governor provisionally, and if I had no objection he might continue to act, until I could present his Commission here for approbation, as was required for all foreign Consuls at the British dependencies abroad, in the same manner as for those residing within the kingdom— I told Mr Morier that I would transmit as soon as possible to the Government of the United States, information of all these Circumstances— I had received no other knowledge than that which he now gave me of any of the incidents to which he had reference. I should no doubt receive Instructions with regard to the deposit of the Naval Stores— I had no doubt of Mr Henry’s appointment at Gibraltar, and could have no objection to his being recognized in the manner proposed; though I had no official knowledge of his appointment.— I enquired for Mr Fox’s Commission, which was not yet ready; and about Mr Bagot’s departure, which I find is still postponed. Returned home between four & five.

12. IX:30. I find myself so far able to bear the daylight, that I this day quitted the dressing-chamber, and ceased having fires made both there and in the Bedchamber— Removed to the Drawing Room, in which I passed this day. Took a walk to Brentford—the first time that I have walked beyond the Gates of my house since the 23d: of last Month. It was about two Miles, and the faculty of walking is the greatest enjoyment that I have yet recovered. I wore the silk shade, but had accidentally left my green Glasses at the Office yesterday in town— Charles came last Evening from School, and went with George this Morning to Church— I intended to have gone in the afternoon myself, but Mr G. Joy came and spent a couple of hours with us. He has been himself much indisposed. Two of George’s School-fellows, Buttanshaw and Standen dined with the family, but I could not dine with them— Still being upon a Regimen. One of them told me that during three winter months, November, December and January, there was no afternoon Sermon, delivered at Ealing Church— The only service was the reading of the Evening Prayer.— Charles returned with Buttanshaw and Standen to School in the Evening— Mrs Adams was very unwell— She had read to me this morning Buckminster’s Sermon upon the Epistle of Paul to Philemon— George also resumed this day his Bible reading; after an intermission of eighteen days. He had ceased with Genesis Chapter 48. And this day began with the 49th. I read one of the six chapters, but found it too strong a trial for my eye, and I was obliged to omit the comparison with the Latin Bible.

13. IX:15. A very tempestuous night and day. Sent Pio into Town again for our Russian baggage, but he returned in the Evening without having effected any thing, in consequence of the badness of the weather. The boatmen did not attend— I began this day, anew my usual course of walking, and went round by Gunnersbury house; returning through Brentford; after which I took a ride with John upon the road to Harrow— Towards Evening, the storm of wind abated, and the weather cleared away, cold. Mr Studley and Mr Service came out with a Letter of recommendation to me from Mr John West, an American Projector, Inventor, and Patent-hunter, who came over here from America, to procure Patents— These two men are Englishmen of the same character & description— Extremely illiterate, but authors or possessors as they profess of innumerable useful and important inventions— Studley himself and Service’s son, are as they told me going to America, and wish to introduce there, under patent privileges, Gaz-lights, Iron pavements, a new method of bleaching flax, and I know not how many more improvements that are to change the face of the world. They kept me certainly more than an hour descanting upon their various schemes, explaining them to me most unintelligibly, and enquiring whether in my opinion they would be useful, and successful in America— I told them that what was found usefull and successful in this Country, would in all probability be found so in that;—and that if they were going to America, for the purpose of making the experiment I would give them Letters to some of my friends who might assist them in procuring their Patents; and if it should be necessary, an alteration of the Patent Law itself to facilitate their obtaining them. But they spoke to me of so many different projects, that I requested them to furnish me a list of those for which they proposed to obtain Patents, which they promised to do, and to send or bring to the Office in Charles Street, next Saturday.— I had a fire made this day in my Library-Room, intending to return to it to-morrow— On Saturday last we brought out from Hookham’s circulating Library the novel or Romance of Guy Mannering, and this day Mrs Adams began reading it to me— I have scarcely steadiness of Spirits enough to resume the Light of Nature.

14. IX. I returned this day for the first time since the attack upon my eyes into my library chamber, and attempted to read and write again— I first took up this Volume, and wrote the three lines at the bottom of page 328. I could write no more, for I found my eyes too
weak to bear the exertion, and I must for some time longer forbear the use of the pen. Nor is the complaint in my eyes my only, or even my greatest difficulty— My hand has been also much affected by my illness, and I can scarcely write with it at-all. I sent Pio into town again for the baggage, and afterwards went in myself, taking, my Son John with me.— The Coachman changed his horses— I was in town upwards of three hours, and so much engaged the whole time with visitors at the Office, that I had not leisure to read the Letters that I found there— The visitors were—A Mrs: Thompson, a sort of crazy woman, pretending to be an American, and to wish to go to America— She acknowledged that she had not been in America for thirty years, and that she was married to an Italian. She complained of having been excessively ill-treated by the American Consul at Liverpool, by a Captain of some vessel who had engaged to take her to New-York, and then sailed without her, and by multitudes of other persons— Indeed of almost every body, English and American— She came to me, to demand that I should procure a passage for her to New-York— On being informed that this was not in my power, she railed at me, as much as she had at Mr Maury, and after talking perhaps half an hour, she went away— Sometime after she came again and asked for a Passport to go to America— She had and could produce no document whatever to shew herself to be an American— I therefore declined giving the Passport. She railed and raved again till she was tired, and went away—a few minutes after she returned a third time with a message from Mr Capper of the Alien-Office, recommending her to me for a Passport as a document upon which they might give her one, there— I still declined— At length Mr Capper himself came, and again recommended to me to give her a Passport— I told him that the rule I had adopted to grant no Passport, but upon satisfactory evidence that the person asking it as an American was really such, had been for the sake of being sure not to trespass upon the prohibitory English Laws, and that if I departed from the principle in one instance, I should not know where to stop; and might unwarily give Passports to persons who were not permitted to go out of the kingdom. He then asked me, if he should send the woman to me again, but I told him it would be to no purpose.— She did not again return. The next visitor was Mr Bennett, from Alexandria— His business here is to endeavour to obtain from the British Government, compensation for the property plundered from him, and from other inhabitants of that place, by the British Officers, on their expedition against it, in August 1814.— Mr: Bennett wished for the aid of my official interposition, but I was convinced, and told him that if I should at all interfere in the case it would operate against his application rather than for it. I recommended him to Mr Murray, the Solicitor, to draw up a Memorial for him to the Lords of the Treasury, who perhaps if applied to upon grounds clear of all diplomatic claims, might possibly be disposed to do justice to the sufferers. I promised him however to give him every assistance in my power, if any opportunity should occur, in which I could promote the object of his claim. He was scarcely gone, when Mr Hughes, the young Gentleman who is to go out as private Secretary to Mr Bagot came in— He told me that they should certainly not sail before Christmas, and probably not before the month of January.— The reason now assigned for the delay is that they cannot man the frigate, the Niger; which is appointed to take them to America— He says that one of the Lieutenants was here last week, and said that they had not obtained thirty men in six weeks— But he said there were other Captains who had declared that their whole crews had offered voluntarily to enter, and there were many who could answer for two thirds. Mr Hughes said that both Mr and Mrs Bagot were very anxious and impatient to be gone, and spoke of the delay as a great disappointment to him— The other visits were from Mr Shaw, of South Carolina, and Mr Joy, who came with Mr Alston the Painter— The last time that I had seen this Gentleman, was at his painting room in Boston, seven or eight years since. Mr Joy gave me some late American Newspapers. The Letters that I received were from Mr Fox at Falmouth, Mr. Bourne at Amsterdam, and Mr Harris at St: Petersburg.— Mr Harris’s Letter as usual is full of speculative politics. The principal object of Mr Bourne’s is, to consult me, concerning the education of his eldest Son, whom he proposes to send to America, to pass through Harvard University— We came home about five O’Clock— Pio came back from the Custom-House, leaving the baggage still there, and returned home with us— Going into town I walked from the Kensington gate to the Office 2 1/2 miles, and returning home, from the fourth milestone to my house 3 3/4 miles. I brought out a Letter for my wife
which had been sent to the Office, by the Chevalier de Freire, the Portuguese Minister— It was from Madame Bezerra, at Rio-Janeiro— Passed the Evening in hearing George recite, and Mrs Adams read Guy Mannering.

15. IX. Sent Pio once more, and for the last time into town after the baggage.— I had directed him to come with it in the boat; but he was unwell, and found it cold; so that he left the Boat, at the Strand Bridge, came out in the Stage, and waited for the boat at Kew-Bridge— It arrived there in the Evening, but too late for the baggage, to be brought to the house this day. Pio wrote me a note from a Public House at the Bridge to inform me of its arrival, and to enquire, if he should stay there over Night to come with it to morrow— I directed that he should— I had a note in the Evening from Mr Grubb, enclosing some American Newspapers, and a Card from Mr Wiggin— He also informs me that the Galen has arrived; sailed from Boston 21. October.— Mrs Adams wrote for me the minutes of my Journal, for the last week.— I walked to Acton and Hanwell; about six Miles— Met Dr Nicholas riding on horseback— He recognized and spoke to me after having passed by without knowing me. My green eye-glasses are a sort of mask. George returned home from school this Evening quite unwell, and did not read.

16. IX. On rising this morning, I found the ground powdered with Snow that had fallen in the Night—The first of this Season, and it soon melted away— It is quite early for Snow in this Country. Having reoccupied during the day time my library-room, I made this day a second effort to write, and answered the two Letters received from Mrs Eliza Giles, and the invitation from Messrs Fox and Schwabe, the Secretaries of the British and foreign school Society, to attend the meeting of that Institution, next Saturday week— I found my eyes and hand yet unable to do more, and must still postpone the recommencement of my Journal. I walked to Gunnersbury and Brentford. About Noon, Pio arrived with our baggage from Kew-Bridge. 34 Trunks and Packages. They were housed as soon as it was found practicable, and appearing to have taken some external damage, we began immediately to unpack them. Several of the boxes of the books were brought into my Library— We opened them and found the Books all very damp, and in danger of moulding, but as few of them actually injured as could have been expected. They employed George and myself during the remainder of the day-light— Charles came home from school to dinner and returned in the Evening. Mr Grubb sent me out a Packet, containing a Letter from Commodore Decatur, dated, Bay of Tunis 31. July and containing an account of his Transactions there, and at Tripoli; with copies of his Letters to the Prime Minister of the Bey and the Bashaw— There was enclosed a similar despatch addressed to Mr Bayard, as the Minister of the United States at St. Petersburg. They were both cut through and through in two places, as are almost all the Letters coming from Barbary, I suppose by some quarantine regulation— George made up the loss of his yesterdays reading by a double portion this day. This Evening Mrs Adams finished reading to me the novel, or romance of Guy Mannering, or the Astrologer—professedly a picture of Scottish manners, Society and characters, about thirty years ago—the time is during the war of the American Revolution. The Story is in a very high degree interesting— The characters, universally coloured beyond Nature, but drawn with a masterly hand, deeply shaded, and well preserved, throughout— The gypsey and the smuggler are sublime absurdities— The proportion of tragic incidents is too great. There is no useful moral that I can discern to be gathered either from the general tenor of the Story, and the purest models of virtue in the work, are the gypsey hag, covered with infamy, and a sort of literary Caliban, covered with ridicule— The best secondary characters are a noble-spirited Scotch farmer given to drink; and a waggish Scotch lawyer given to wine— The worst feature of the book is its tendency to countenance superstition— Mannering is a Gentleman educated in the 18th. century at an English University, who yet studies astrology— He casts a nativity at the birth of a child; it portends the strangest events, all of which come to pass— The old gypsey too is a perpetual oracle, and always a true prophetess— The Castle of Otranto was all the original of all these mixtures of antient superstitions with modern manners, and none of them that I have seen is more amusing or less instructive than Guy Mannering— The author’s name is not given, but it is generally attributed to Walter Scott.

17. IX. We continued all the Morning, unpacking the baggage from St Petersburg. The boatman with whom Mr Grubb had agreed to bring it all from the Custom-house to Kew-Bridge, for £2. took advantage of his promise, that he should if he was careful, have the job of bringing it from the Bridge to the house, without stipulating for that part of the price of his service, to impose upon me— He first claimed £3. for the boating instead of £2— Then £1:5 for carting the things to the house, and 12 shillings for two men, who helped loading and unloading— It was with great difficulty that at last I dismissed him with £4. for the whole— We dined at Mr Copland’s, at Gunnersbury.
George was invited, and obtained a furlough from School to go— The Company at dinner were Dr Nicholas, his two eldest daughters, and his son Frank, Coll: Stapleton, Coll: Ramsey, Major and Mrs Morison, and Miss Batty— Mr Copland’s son William, a young man of eighteen, just from Eton School, was also there. Miss Blair and Miss Carnell came in after dinner. We had music by Mrs Copeland, Miss Batty and Miss Nicholas’s— Coll. Stapleton, who is either a native of South Carolina, or has an Estate there, and has been much in America, told me that he was going to the United States in the Niger frigate, with Mr Bagot; and expected to sail in a few days— He was much surprized, and apparently disappointed when I told him there was no prospect of his going sooner than January, if then. We came home about 11 O’Clock— The Snow of yesterday morning has been succeeded by sharp cold, and a hard frost— As this was the first time that I have ventured out into company since my illness, and as I am still upon an abstemious regimen, I was concerned for its effect upon my eyes, and hesitated whether I should not send an excuse— I got through the day and Evening however without much injury— The light of the fire and candles was rather too strong for me, and after dinner I wore my green silk shade. I received this day two packets from Mr Grubb—that of the Evening, when we came home from Gunnersbury— It enclosed Letters from America for all the family; only one of them for myself and that was from my brother.

18. IX. George has been several days troubled with a bad cold and cough, and was this day so unwell that he could not go to School. As I find myself able again to read, though little at a time, I begin once more to frequent my library, when I rise in the morning before Breakfast. This morning I received Letters from Mr Richard M’Call, Navy Agent for the American Squadron in the Mediterranean, and appointed Consul of the United States at Barcelona, in Spain— He writes me from Gibraltar, and informs me that Commodores Bainbridge and Decatur had just sailed from thence, returning to America, leaving Commodore Shaw with two frigates and two sloops of War in the Mediterranean— A long Letter from Mr Shaler, now our Consul at Algiers, dated at that place 25. September, contains much valuable information of the situation of that Country. He thinks its force very contemptible— A Letter from Messrs: Alexander Glennie, Son and Co: dated yesterday mentions that Mr Richard M’Call had drawn, and was drawing Bills upon them to the amount of £17000 beyond the remittances made to them by the Navy Department— That £9000 of these Bills, were noted for non-acceptance, and would not be paid unless in the meantime they should receive the funds. I went into London, and found at the Office a Card of invitation to dinner, next Friday, with Mr Vansittart, the Chancellor of Exchequer, which I answered and accepted— A Note from Mr Morier’s with information that the Exequatur, for Mr Fox, as Consul of the United States at Falmouth, was at the foreign Office ready to be delivered— And a Letter from Mr William Lee, Consul at Bordeaux with a packet, containing two copies of a work published by him, in French, entitled Les Etats Unis et l’Angleterre— They were brought by a Captain Skinner who left them at the Office yesterday. One copy of the Book is for myself— The other to be returned to Captain Skinner, for a friend of Mr Lee’s in London. I called at the Foreign Office, took Mr Fox’s Commission and Exequatur, paid £9:19 for the fees, and left the Papers, with Mr. Grubb, to be sent to Messrs Foxes and Hamilton in the City, as Mr Fox the Consul had requested. A Captain Very called at the Office, and represented himself to have been shipwrecked, and to be wanting now to borrow £5: to enable him to return to America— He said he was a Relation, of Mr W. Gray of Boston, and offered me a Bill upon his father Samuel Very, living at Salem— He had no documents or testimony to authenticate his Story, but there was so much of that Evidence which truth carries along with itself, in his narrative and in his personal appearance, that I lent him the money, and took his order upon his father— He was going immediately to Gravesend, where there was he said a vessel, the Captain of which was an acquaintance of his, and had promised him a passage to Boston. Soon after he left the Office, Mr John Chipman Gray, son of Mr W. Gray of Boston, Mr Parkman, and a Mr Parker, all of Boston came in— They all arrived in the Galen. Coll. Aspinwall, the appointed Consul for the Port of London, came with his family in the same Ship. These Gentlemen landed somewhere on the Coast.— The Coll: comes to Gravesend in the vessel— Mr Gray had been out to Quincy, before he sailed from Boston, and brought me Letters from my father and Mother— And also a Letter from his own father.
I enquired of Mr Gray, concerning Captain Very who had been just before him at the office— He had not seen him, but said that he had kinsmen of that name residing at Salem, and that he had no doubt that this Mr Very’s Story had been true as he told it. I returned home about five O’Clock, and walked from the fourth mile-stone. It was dark before I reached home.

19. IX. George continues to read to me in the French Bible, though his cough is very troublesome and makes it difficult— And as I am not yet strong enough to resume my early rising hours, he has no fixed time of the day for reading; but takes it according to his engagements at School, morning or Evening— I attended Church alone, the first time for these four weeks; Mr Lewis read prayers, and Mr Carr of Brighton preached the Sermon— Neither his composition nor his delivery are above mediocrity. After church I took a walk of nearly two hours round through Hanwell and Brentford— As I was going to church I had met Dr Cook, who stopped and enquired if I was not exposing myself too soon— I assured him that I had derived much benefit and no injury from the exercise that I had taken— Mrs. Adams paid visits to Mrs Morison and Mrs Von Harten— She took John with her, who has recovered from his illness. I received a Letter from Mr Harris dated at St. Petersburg 10/22 April last— He had then enclosed it under cover to Messrs: Willink at Amsterdam, and they had forwarded it by Post to the care of Messrs: Hottinguer and Co. at Paris— It had then been stopped at the frontiers, and there is nothing to shew how or by whom it has been transmitted to me now— Mrs Adams this Evening began reading to me this Evening Waverly, another Scotch novel or Romance, of which Walter Scott is the reputed author.— Weather moderated.

20. IX. John returned this morning to School, with George— He had shewn last Evening some little reluctance, but went off this morning very cheerfully— I heard them go, about the dawn of day, and before I rose— I was employed the greatest part of the day in arranging in my library the Books arrived from St Petersburg, which are too numerous for the bookcases and for the size of my room— An inconvenience to which I have been subjected almost my whole life time, and from which I have no prospect of being ever relieved unless by diminishing the Library itself. I took a walk of six miles through Ealing, Acton, Gunnersbury and Brentford— Mrs Adams brought up the arrears in the minutes for my Journal.— Received in the Evening a Note from Mr Grubb, enclosing a Letter to my wife from Mr Robert Boyd, at Paris. It was brought by Mr A Belknap, together with a box, containing some Articles for which Mrs. Adams had written to Mr Boyd— Mr Belknap sent them yesterday, with a note from himself to the Office— Mr Grubb mentions also a Mr Frederick Pursh as having called at the Office, and wishing to see me.

21. VIII. The Letter which I received last Saturday from Messrs: Alexander Glennie, Son and Co: led me to the determination of calling upon Messrs: Baring Brothers and Co. to see whether funds could be obtained for the payment of Mr M’Call’s Bills, which the Glennie’s have suffered to be noted for non-acceptance. I went therefore into town early this morning. Took Pio with me— Called first at Mr Alexander Baring’s house to enquire, whether he had returned from his tour upon the Continent. He had returned; but was at his Counting house in the City. I stopped at the house of Mr Chester the Master of the Ceremonies and left a Card— Called at the Portuguese Ambassador’s house in the same Street, but I found that the Chevalier de Freire the Minister has not yet removed from Baker Street— I had taken a letter from Mrs Adams to Madame Bezerra, at Rio Janeiro intending to request Mr de Freire to forward it; but finding he was not there, and not having time to go to Baker Street, I concluded to have Mrs Adams’s letter sent to him by the Post, and proceeded down to Bishopsgate Street, within Number 8. where I found Mr Alexander Baring. He returned only three or four days since from France, and shewed me Letters which he had received last Saturday from Mr Dallas, the Secretary of the Treasury— They announced to him a remittance of £130,000 Sterling, and requested the house to make a remittance of 750,000 florins to the Bankers of the United States at Amsterdam. He said they had already written to Amsterdam, authorizing the Willink’s and Van Staphorst’s to draw upon them to the amount of the sum mentioned by Mr Dallas. I was much rejoiced to find that this large remittance had been so seasonably made from America, and told Mr Baring that my principal motive for calling upon him now, was to ask him if his house could with convenience supply funds to the amount of fifteen or twenty thousand pounds Sterling, for the discharge of Bills, drawn by Mr M’Call navy Agent of the United States at Gibraltar, upon Glennie, Son & Co here, beyond the remittances which that house had received from the Navy Department— Mr Baring said they would very readily furnish the funds to take up these bills, at my request— All they wanted in such cases was authority— Mr M’Call had written to them, requesting them to take up these Bills, if Messrs: Glennie, should decline so to do, but there had some time ago, been an Instruction from the Treasury Department directing that no payments of this kind, relating to the expenditures on account of seamen should be made, unless authorized by a Minister of the United States. If therefore I would write a line to the house requesting them to provide for the
payment of the Bills, it should immediately be done— I told him that I would see the Messrs Glennie, and consult with them, upon the most convenient manner of doing the business, and then write the letter, as he desired. I had some further conversation with Mr Baring upon his late tour to the Continent which he extended farther than he had intended—he went not only to France, and Switzerland; but into part of Germany and Italy— He left his two Sons at Geneva—at School— I enquired of him how he liked the institutions for education there— He said they were very good for the Mathematics, Natural and experimental Philosophy, and the French language; but for classical learning, the Latin and Greek, not equal to the Schools of this Country.— He had seen Madame de Stael, at Copet— She is now gone, he says, or going to Rome, and perhaps to Jerusalem.— The project of marriage between her daughter & the Duke de Broglie, is resumed— As for her Son she says he is “Bête, comme son Pere”— I went from Mr Baring to the Counting house of Messrs: Glennie. Neither of those Gentlemen, father or Son was there—but I saw Mr Fry, their partner— He gave me a statement of all the drafts upon them by Mr M’Call, beyond the remittances received by them from the Navy Department— It amounted, not as they had written me, to £17000, but to £12800— I then told him that the Bills would be taken up, by the house of the Baring’s, who would either accept the Bills, or supply the funds upon which they, the Glennie’s would accept them— Mr Fry appeared to think that the conduct of his house needed some apology, but he made it aukwardly. He said the Navy Department had remitted only £15000 for the wants of the Squadron in the Mediterranean— That a remittance of £15000 for such an object was ridiculous. That £10,000 of it had been expended in repairs upon one of the Ships, of damages sustained in the action with the Algerines—or perhaps upon the Algerine prize carried into Carthagena. That they had been many years agents of the Navy Department; that during the War between the United States and Tripoli, or when there was about that time a large American Squadron in the Mediterranean, they had been for sometime in advance to the amount of at least £20,000 Sterling. That the money had been afterwards paid them it was true; but that the American Government had never so much as said to them “thank you,” for it— That Mr Erving was at that time the American Consul, and agent for various purposes— He had a large sum of public money at his disposal; and had proposed to them to pay that balance, with this money, and then draw Bills upon the Secretary of the Navy, at 3 shillings for the Dollar, the exchange to be for his own benefit— They had told him that as the money with which he would pay them belonged to the United States, the benefit of the exchange ought to be for the public and not for his private interest— And he had drawn accordingly; so that by their means the United States had lost nothing upon the Exchange.— They had always been careful for the interests of the United States; but they had never received any thanks for it, and had no encouragement to make advances for them. I did not chuse to enter into a discussion with Mr Fry, but took the minute which he made out of the balance due to discharge Mr M’Call’s Bills, and told him that Messrs: Baring would arrange with them the manner of taking them up.— As Mr Travers the oculist, lives in the same Street, with the Glennie’s, I called at his house, with the intention of consulting him again about my eyes; but he was not at home— I then went to the Office in Charles Street, but it was near four O’Clock when I reached there— Coll: Aspinwall and Captain Stuart had been at the Office, and waited for me there nearly two hours, but were gone. A Mr Nickels was there, who has a claim upon the British Government, for a vessel of his seized in a port of this Country under particular Circumstances at the commencement of the late War— The case differs from that transmitted to me by Messrs: Derby and Prince’s only in the Circumstance that this vessel had but just returned from a Voyage in which she had been freighted upon British Account, when she was seized.— This Gentleman wished for my official interposition in his favour, but I told him of our unsuccessful endeavours to obtain at Ghent a provision for such cases; and the positive refusal of the British Government, with their explicit declaration that they would break off the negotiation if we persisted in the demand— I assured him his claim would have a better chance without my interference than with it— He asked me if I could furnish him with any document to shew the course pursued in America, with regard to British Vessels in the same predicament. I told him I had the decision and opinion of Judge Davis, District Judge of Massachusetts, which had been sent me— I promised to bring it with me to town and lend it to him.— It was about six O’Clock when I came home.

22. VIII. Having failed of meeting Coll: Aspinwall yesterday, I determined to go into town again this day, and Mr Grubb called last Evening at his lodgings and informed him that I would see him there at 2 O’Clock, to go with him and present his Commission, at the foreign Office— I went first to the Office in Charles Street, where I found a Mr Porter who is going to America, and offered to take Letters or Dispatches— I had given him a Passport some time in July, and he now came for another— Mr Shaw came to take leave. He is to embark for Charleston to-morrow. The vessel in which he has taken passage was seized; but by the interest of Lord Lowther he obtained her release— I went to the foreign Office to inform Mr Morier or Mr Hamilton, that I should come with Coll: Aspinwall, but neither of them was at the Office— I went down to the Colls. lodgings at Walker’s Hotel in Bridge Street, and saw him, his Lady, and Captain Stuart, whom he introduced to me as his Secretary. The Coll: gave me two Letters from my father, and Captain Stuart a Letter of introduction from Mr Saml: Dexter of Boston. Coll: Aspinwall has only the Commission as Consul for the Port of London, without that of Agent for Seamen, which had a Salary annexed to it— Upon the single Commission of Consul he must very soon starve. I told him I heard he had contemplated a commercial establishment, as subsidiary to his Office; he said he should perhaps be forced to resort to it as a resource, but that he had neither education nor experience as a merchant, nor relish for the business— He said he had been much deceived in his anticipations respecting the profits of the Consulate, until a very few days before he had embarked at Boston, when he had heard that they were inconsiderable— I mentioned Mr Grubb to the Coll: as having been formerly under General Lyman a Clerk in the Consular Office, and a person whom I could strongly recommend to him for a similar situation. He said that his friend Captain Stuart had come out with him as his Secretary, and it was doubtful whether he could afford the expence of employing another person; but if he could, he would certainly employ Mr Grubb. I had received at the Office a Letter from Mr Ingraham, soliciting my good-offices to represent to Coll: Aspinwall the case of the Consulate at Plymouth— Mr Ingraham being informed that Mr Hawker was seeking recommendations to the Coll:— I mentioned to him Mr Ingraham’s situation, and the circumstances relating to it; but the Commission of Consul at the Port of London, does not include Plymouth within the extent of its authority; and the Coll: could of course not interfere in the affair— He said he had received also a Letter from Mr Ingraham, and one from Mr Hawker, who had sent him several certificates of recommendation, from persons, only one of whom was known to him—and that was Mr T. H. Perkins; a Gentleman, who however respectable his character might be, would probably not have much influence with the Government of the United States, having taken so decided a part in the affair of the Hartford Convention.— He had also been informed that at the time of the captures of American Vessels, under the orders in Council, Mr Hawker had sometimes been the agent both of the captors and of the captured; which shewed his unfitness for the Office of American Consul— But the Coll: said he had determined not to interfere at all, in regard to the Consulate at Plymouth— He went with me to the foreign Office, where I presented him to the two Under-Secretaries of State, Messrs: Morier and Hamilton. He gave his Commission to Mr Morier, to obtain the exequatur— I returned with him to his lodgings; he invited me to stay and dine with him, but I was expected at home, and immediately returned— I walked from the Hammersmith Turnpike into town, and from the fourth mile-stone home— While I was at the Office, Mr Grubb had written a Letter, which I dictated, to Messrs: Baring Brothers conformably to the conversation I had yesterday with Mr Alexander Baring— I had yesterday received a Letter from Mr Jackson, our Chargé d’Affaires at Paris, enclosing a copy of an Official Note from him to the Duke de Richelieu, the French Minister of foreign Affairs, remonstrating against the assessment of excessive contributions upon Mr Fenwick at Bordeaux, and other American Citizens residing in France— Mr Jackson also asks very pointedly my opinion of his diplomatic communications. I also brought home last Evening the box, brought from Paris, by Mr Belknap for Mrs Adams, containing some articles of dress, procured for her by Mr R. Boyd.

23. VIII:30. While I was in Town Yesterday, there was a great stir and hubbub among the female Servants of the house; against whom Mrs. Adams had received strong and well founded complaints. They had no defence against the charges, and could only resort to mutual criminations against one another. Mrs Adams gave notice to three of them, Mrs Brooks the Cook, Margaret Wedge, the housemaid, and Ann Prudden the Laundry maid— They are accordingly to quit at the expiration of a Month, from the day of notice— There was an attempt made last Night to break open the house— My Son George, Lucy Hauel my wife’s chambermaid, and Richard Brant the English footmen, were all waked by the noise, and got up; though lodging in different parts of the house— Richard finally thought it was only a rat between the walls; but Lucy said she heard a whistling.— The attempt however happily proved abortive— This morning, Mrs Adams brought up all the arrears in the minutes of the Journal, and also wrote for me three Letters which I dictated— One, in answer to those of 16. Octr: and of the 10th: instt. received from Mr. Jackson at Paris— The second in Answer to General La Fayette’s Letter of 7. October which Mr Jackson forwarded
to me, and the third, in answer to Mr Harris’s Letters at St: Petersburg, of 22. April, 23 August, 16. September, & 14. October. As my eyes are still too weak, and my right hand too unsteady to write, my wife has kindly offer to write for me— Having never been accustomed to dictate writing to others, I now find myself aukward at the practice, but it enables me to resume my correspondence, which has been so long, and almost entirely suspended on my part— So that in the course of five weeks the accumulation of Letters to be answered has become very great— The minutes for my Journal, and the Letter to my mother which my Mother wrote for me were experiments; and from this day she will write for me, long and often.— In the Evening, after dinner she reads to me, and we are now engaged upon Waverly— Mr Grubb sent me out this Evening a Letter from Mr James B. Murray, dated 28 August last, just before he left England, mentioning that he was obliged to go, and that he had left his affair of the Nanina, with Messrs: Greg, Lindsay & Co: whom he recommends to my attention, and to any assistance that I can give them in this affair. The Letter was left at the Office yesterday, and Mr Lindsay will call to see me there to-morrow— I received also this Evening an anonymous Letter.

24. VIII. A Mr Lock, son of a Custom-House Officer to whom Mr Grubb and Pio were referred by Mr: M’Lean, to get our baggage cleared from the Custom-House, sent me a bill of £15:8. Sterling for Lighterage, Cartage, gratuities, Commission &c— It is understood that my baggage was professedly admitted free, and that all these charges are mere extortions of the Officers and their Sharks, as Grubb calls them— Creatures whom they employ to do this work for them, so that they the Officers may not appear in it themselves, and be liable to be turned out for malversation.— I gave Mr Grubb this Bill to ascertain what was the amount of the charges upon it, proper to be paid; he sent it back to me reduced to £10:5— I received it this morning, with two Letters, from my father, and my mother, left at the Office, by Mr Reynolds of Boston who brought them and came passenger in the Galen— My wife wrote for me a short Letter to my father— We had a visit from Mr Dickason— I went into London, and walked from the Hammersmith Turnpike to my Office— I found there a Letter from Messrs: Baring Brothers & Co: dated yesterday, in answer to mine of the day before to them— They have arranged with the Glennie’s the acceptance and payment of Mr M’Call’s Bills.— They even complied with the wish of the Glennie’s, who were tenacious of accepting them, although they refused the advances to pay for them— I should have preferred that the acceptance should have been made by the Baring’s, that the transaction might have appeared in its true light. Mr Lindsay called at the Office upon Mr Murray’s business. He was of opinion that they would need an authorization from me, to enter an appeal, from the Sentence of the Admiralty Court, concerning the Nanina, and although I was doubtful whether it could be of any service to the cause, I consented to give them a written approbation, which they are to request, likewise in writing. Mr Grubb left the Office at four O’Clock, when the dusk now already begins; and I sat musing by the fire-side, unable to read or write, and half determining to return home to Ealing to-Night, until the dinner hour, of seven, came— I dined at Mr Vansittart’s. The Lords, Bathurst, Harrowby, Melville, and Tyrconnel, Baron Fagel, the Dutch Ambassador and his brother, Baron Jacobi the Prussian, and Mr Bourke, the Danish Minister, Mr Neumann the Austrian Charge des Affaires, Lord Lowther, Mr Beckett, the Under Secretary of State in the Home Department, and several other Gentlemen, chiefly or all foreigners, formed the Company. I was seated at table, between Lord Melville and Baron Jacobi, with both of whom I had various conversation. Lord Melville, asked me several questions, respecting the American Squadron which has been at Gibraltar— He is the first Lord of the Admiralty, and has doubtless received particular information concerning it— There was much more general Conversation than is usual at such parties, and it very much enlivened the company— The topics were indeed not very important— Pedestrianism, Boxing, Cock-fighting, and a sort of historical commentary upon the house in which Mr Vansittart resides and all the houses in the neighbourhood, from Charles the Second, the Duke of Monmouth and Nell Gwynn, down to Sir Robert Walpole— It was on the whole amusing, and there was much social good humour and conviviality. Mr Vansittart mentioned after dinner, that there was now here an American, named Edwards, but Lord Tyrconnel said it was Adams, who had been at Tombuctoo, and remained there several Months. He said it was a City about as large as Lisbon— He had brought nothing certain respecting Mungo Park, but several particulars tending
to confirm the account of his Death. It was near eleven when the Company left Mr Vansittart’s, and I returned to pass the Night at Charles Street. The Condition of my eyes still requires caution and a degree of abstemiousness, not easy to observe at such entertainments as these. I had also the further admonition, of a Cold which has been coming upon me these three days. I was as careful, and suffered as little inconvenience from the party as I could have expected.

25. VII: I had ordered the Coachman, to be at the door for me, as soon after Seven O’Clock this morning as he could. I rose at that hour, which is just at day light.— The Carriage came half an hour later— As the morning was fine, I got out at the Kensington Turnpike, by the second Milestone and walked the rest of the way home, a little short of six Miles.— I got home before ten O’Clock just in time for Breakfast— Mrs Adams wrote Letters for me, in answer to those of Mr M’Call of 11. Octr: dated at Gibraltar, of Mr Alexander Hammett, the Consul at Naples, dated 13. Octr: and of Mr Robt. Mowbray at Leith of the 6th: instant— She also began a Letter to Mr Bourne, at Amsterdam in answer to his of the 14th All these Letters have been laying sometime unanswered, owing to my indisposition— I took again a short walk at the hour of dusk, before dinner; a couple of miles. John and Charles came home from School— George read to me; but he and myself have both bad Colds and have proceeded not without difficulty, in the french reading without losing a day since the 12th.— I received a third Letter from Mrs Eliza Giles of Watford, dated yesterday, and proposing to me to pawn some fine table linen to me, for a sum of money, under the expectation that the American Government would allow me to make a charge for the payment, as any liberal government in her opinion would do.— In which case I should restore to her, the table linen. Another Letter from the Willink’s and Van Staphorst’s at Amsterdam dated the 21st. urges with renewed importunity for the payment of the public balance due to them; and manifests great concern at their having then received no remittances from the Treasury of the United States.— This Letter I am happily enabled to answer without difficulty. Mrs Adams finished reading Waverly, or ’tis sixty years since, to me, this Evening— This is a novel by the same author as Guy Mannering, and was published before it— In the same style, but not of equal merit— The Scenery is again in Scotland, but the time is thirty years sooner, and at the period of the rebellion of 1745. Prince Charles Edward is one of the principal characters in it, and most of the characters excepting Waverly himself are Scotch. The hero, is a weak and wavering personage, who is drawn into rebellion by untoward circumstances, and a want of steady principles. The moral to be collected from it is therefore more dear and important than that of the Astrologer— And the fable is well constructed for the deduction of the moral from the action. It is doubtful whether firmness can be given to weak minds by any instructions, yet it must be useful to expose the fatal consequences that may flow from instability— It is however difficult to take any interest in the adventures of so feeble and irresolute a hero as Waverly, and the interest of this Story is accordingly heavy and languishing through the first and second Volumes— The third is better— Charles Edward is a paragon of perfection— Fergus M’Ivor and his Sister Flora, are Jacobite fanatics, with all the sublimity of Treason upon principle— Fergus finishes upon a gibbet, and Flora in a french Nunnery. There is one burlesque character a military, classical and genealogical Pedant, a Traitor from fidelity, but who like Waverly is pardoned for his insignificancy.— There is some food for Superstition—Second Sight, and an Apparition—introduced however only in narration. On the whole, both the books are far above the ordinary Class of Novels.

26. VIII:30. The fatigue of my yesterday’s walks somewhat delayed my hour of rising this Morning. We all went to Church— The services were all performed by Mr Lewis— The Sermon from the lst: Psalm verse 2—very indifferent.— After Church, I walked with George, through Acton, Turnham Green and Brentford home, about six Miles— I made a new attempt to write, and answered the Letters of Mrs Giles, and of Messrs: Willink and Van Staphorst at Amsterdam— But the writing or the candle-light somewhat aggravated the inflammation of my left eye, which is yet far from having entirely subsided— Mrs Von Harten paid a visit to Mrs: Adams— John and Charles returned this Evening to School. I received Letters from Messrs: Greg Lindsay and Co: and from Mr Beasley; the latter enclosing one from Mr Russell, our Minister Plenipotentiary at Stockholm— The first contains the request to me, in behalf of Mr Murray, to sanction the entry of an appeal from the Sentence of the Admiralty Court, in the Case of the Nanina. Mr Russell’s Letter is a long one, and is in answer to that which I wrote to him, on the 10th: of October— Mrs Adams began reading to me Miss Edgeworth’s Tales of fashionable life— The first Volume is filled with Ennui, the first part of which is almost as tiresome as the title itself threatens.

27. VI. As I find myself gradually, though very slowly recovering from the disease with which I have been afflicted, I am endeavouring to resume as soon as possible the industrious habits of my life, which it has interrupted— I rose this Morning at six O’Clock, and heard George read by candle-light— When he had finished it was not yet clear day-light, and as I could then neither read nor write, I walked with him
as far as his school, and then continued my walk, round through Ealing, Hanwell and Brentford, about six Miles when I returned home to Breakfast.— When I got back, I found at the house a printed Notification from a Constable requiring me, with in two days, to prepare and produce a list in writing of the names of every man residing in my house between the ages of 18 and 45, to sign the list with my own name, and deliver the same to the Constable, upon a penalty of ten Pounds— The Boy who brought this Notification had left it, saying that he would call for the answer to-morrow— After Breakfast Mrs Adams finished writing the Letter to Mr Bourne, and wrote one to the Secretary of State. We all dined at Dr Nicholas’s— The company consisted of Major and Mrs Morison, Miss Blair and Miss Carnell, Mr and Mrs Copland, their Son William, and Miss Batty, Mr and Mrs Gray, Mr and Mrs: Von Harten, and a Mr Rahles a friend of their’s lately arrived from America— He brought out Mrs Von Harten’s two daughters from New-York, and is to return shortly to the United States.— We had musick and singing after dinner— Mrs Morison and her party of Ladies went away at 9 O’Clock, to attend a rout at Richmond: we came home between 11 and 12. I was too unwell with a cold, as well as with the remaining inflammation and weakness of my left eye to enjoy fully the entertainment.— George’s cough was also very bad. Dr: Nicholas’s son Frank, and his two eldest daughters Caroline and Ellen, dined with us—the two younger daughters, Charlotte and Laura came in after dinner— Mr Gray gave me an invitation to join a small monthly club which these gentlemen are forming to dine together at an Inn, opposite to Dr Nicholas’s school; where they are building an Assembly or Ball-Room. This club formerly subsisted, but was broken up, and they are now proposing to revive it— Last Saturday they had their first meeting and were only four— Mr Gray said the object of this Club at every meeting was to agree upon the day when they should meet again— They had agreed last Saturday that the next meeting should be on Friday the 15th: of next Month and Major Morison, Mr Von Harten and myself were now invited to join them, which we all promised to do.— I received under a cover from Lord Bathurst, the Gazette Extraordinary of the 23d: instant, announcing the Conclusion of the Peace with France— The Treaties and Conventions were signed on the 20th. instant, by Lord Castlereagh and the Duke of Wellington for this Country, and by the Duke de Richelieu for the king of France. This Evening, the Public Offices in London, were illuminated for it— Mr Copland told us that he had been to town; and found they were preparing to illuminate his house in Great George Street, Westminster.

28. VIII— The lateness of the hour at which we returned from the party yesterday, at Dr Nicholas’s, together with my own & George’s indisposition, again protracted my time of rising this morning until about Sunrise. I received a Letter from Mr: Maury at Liverpool mentioning that he had been told at the Custom-House there, that there had been no alteration in the alien-laws, since the Act of Parliament, passed on the 12th: of May last— On this subject, as well as on those concerning which Mr Hammett, the Consul at Dublin wrote me, I wished to see one of the Under Secretaries of State in the foreign Office, and accordingly went into London this morning— Mrs Adams accompanied me, to make some enquiry after female servants to replace those she has dismissed— I called at the foreign Office, but neither Mr Morier, nor Mr Hamilton was there— Coll: Aspinwall called at the Office; and also Mr: Murray, the Solicitor, of Sun-Court, Cornhill, who came to shew me the Memorial to the Lords of the Treasury which he had drawn for Mr Bennett.— The inhabitants of Alexandria gave up their property by Capitulation; but Mr Bennett nevertheless entertains hopes of recovering indemnity for it, because Admiral Cockburn, had promised that their private property should not be taken, if they made no resistance— Mr Murray has no great expectations, but he thinks justice worth asking for. Mr Grubb wrote as I dictated, an answer to the Letter from Messrs: Greg, Lindsay and Co: approving their entry of an appeal in the case of the Nanina— Two American Sailors came to solicit relief and assistance— One of them is supplied by Mr Beasley to the amount authorized by law, but wanted five shillings to redeem his cloathing, pawned for board and lodging, to enable him to embark to return home— The other, named Oliver Cromwell, has been two or three times shipwrecked, and says he can get no relief at the Consulate. Mr Grubb at my desire wrote to Mr Beasley in his behalf. We returned home about five O’Clock— I had on going into town walked from the Kensington Gate, to the Office in Charles Street— George read to me in the Evening.

29. VI— Rose again and heard George read by candle light— The morning was fine, and from the windows of my library we saw the moon, at the last day of her last quarter, and only 40 hours before the change— The new Moon being at 11 O’Clock to-morrow Evening. We also saw Venus and Jupiter, both shining bright as morning Stars, and nearly in conjunction—about ten minutes distant from
each other. I made up and enclosed to Mr Grubb, ready for this Morning’s Post a parcel of blank Passports, signed, but by waiting for the Postman who did not come the chance was lost, and the packet did not go until the afternoon— Mrs Adams wrote two Letters for me— One to Mr Shaler, in answer to those from him of 28 July and 25. September—and one to Mr Eustis, in answer to his of 8. September. I walked through Gunnersbury and Brentford, and met Major Morison walking with Miss Blair and another young Lady.— Mrs Adams this Evening finished reading the tale of Ennui, the latter part of which is very interesting— The moral as in all Miss Edgworth’s writings is excellent.— The change of character in Lord Glenthorne from the most inveterate indolence, to the highest pitch of industry and activity accounted for, as well as perhaps was possible, and the incidents all natural excepting the main spring of the action; the change of the children by the nurse; and that though improbable was necessary to the fable—

30. VII. It was so late that I could not hear George read until after he returned from School— I made the second attempt to resume the writing of my Journal in this book, from the minutes kept from day to day by my wife. My left eye is yet slightly inflamed, and both my eyes are very weak—particularly towards the Evening, and by candle-light— I now wash them every morning with Brandy and Water—substituted since last Monday instead of the Collyrium of Rose-water and alum— My right hand is also yet so unsteady that I write with extreme difficulty. I got through only half a page this morning. I made up and enclosed to Mr Grubb the Letters yesterday written, and Mrs Adams this day wrote for me two more—to President Kirkland, of Harvard University, in answer to that received from him by Mr Bond, and to Mr Spafford of Albany.— Mr Grubb sent me out a Letter from Mr Beasley, in answer to the application which I had directed to be made to him in behalf of Oliver Cromwell, the Sailor— Soon after returning from my walk round through Hanwell and Ealing, I had a visit from a Mr Frederick de Rode, who had already been here while I was out— He announced himself to the Servants as a Count, and had two crosses of military orders of knighthood at his button-hole. He had been at the Office in Charles Street, and expressed such a vehement urgency to see me, this very day, to Mr Grubb, that he gave him the direction to my house— I received him in the drawing room, and as he intimated a wish to have a few words of conversation with me alone, Mrs Adams immediately withdrew. He was young—not more than twenty—handsome in person and with quite a gentleman’s deportment— He wanted to go to America—to enter the military service of the United States— He said he was in the last Stage of desperation— A Saxon by Birth; the Son of a Conseiller intime of the king of Saxony. That two years since, ambitious to contribute his aid to what he considered a good cause, he had entered the Russian Service. He had made the two last Campaigns with distinction, and obtained rank and honours certainly beyond what he could have expected. He was now a Captain of Hussars, and had been among the allied troops who entered France last Summer— But he had suffered himself heedlessly to be drawn into play— He had lost every thing he had in the world; not only every thing he possessed, but he had given assignations upon all his Estates at home. He was totally ruined— And the consequence of his gaming had been a duel— He wished to fly from Europe forever—he could not live there without honour—North-America, South America—India—any where, to be at the greatest possible distance from Europe. He would have preferred South-America, because there was War there, and he should hope to be rendering some Service to a good cause— But he knew not to whom to apply, to enable him to get there— I asked him which side he considered the good cause in that Country to be— He said that of the Independents. I told him that as the Government of the United States had just been reducing their army from sixty to ten thousand men, they had been obliged to discharge great numbers of native meritorious Officers, and there could be no chance for a foreigner to obtain a Commission. That even if it were possible, as the Country was at peace, there was neither profit nor glory to be anticipated in the military service for the present. That if he was irrevocably determined to leave Europe, I should think the British Service in India, was the best of his three projects, and asked him if he had any source of influence through which he could obtain a Commission there— He said that the Duke and Duchess of Cumberland were acquainted with his family, and as for his military he could have the most unexceptionable testimonials; but he felt an invincible repugnance to make application to the Prince— He saw clearly from what I had said, that there would be no chance for him in North-America; and how to get to South America he did not know.— I gave him the name and residence of Mr Del Real, who I told him might have it in his power to put him in the way— But I advised him above all to reconsider his projects— To remember that a Soldier, above all men, ought never to despair— That he should endeavour to calm the agitation of his mind, and rather resort to his father and his natural friends than fly to other worlds— He appeared inflexibly determined against all this, and intimated that he would sooner take to the road (but no, he would
never do that) or put a period to his own existence than return to his own Country. I asked him if he had left the Russian Service— He said not absolutely— He had come away from France about three weeks since— He was unwilling to mention particulars, as consciousness of wrong always is— He had evidently fled and escaped from France, and deserted from the duty of his Regiment. He at length took Mr Del Real’s name and address, and left me, with a request that I would keep his secret, so as not to expose him— I heard from our Servants that he did not immediately return to London, but went to the Plough Inn, and there dismissed his Carriage— Mrs. Adams and George, began reading this Evening Miss Edgworth’s Almeria.

Day. From the beginning of this Month I have been gradually recovering, from the severe illness with which I was afflicted at the close of the last; but the weakness of my eyes and the unsteadiness of my hand, has hitherto made it impossible for me to write or read. I think that for the last thirty years, I never wrote or read so little in any one Month as in this. As my general health has however been good, I have been able partly to resume my occupations— My wife writes for me, and reads to me. My rising hours have in general been three or four later than those of my healthy times; but the rest of the time is employed much as before my illness.— I now rise occasionally at six O’Clock, and I shall henceforth endeavour to retrieve the arrears of this Journal. I began this morning with an arrearage of 47 days. (and am on the 22d: day of December, writing this.) My Correspondence has also fallen into arrears, which it may be more difficult to retrieve.
